awd_titl_txt: Promoting persistence of underprivileged college students in science and mathematics through engagement of their families
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation (NSF) Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) project at Pacific University in Forest Grove, Oregon will award scholarships to 36 low-income, academically talented students, and provide the recipients specialized on-campus programing. Both freshmen and transfer students will be eligible for these scholarships. Scholarships will be offered to qualified students in biology, chemistry, computer science, environmental science, mathematics, and physics. Elements in the program will include targeted academic support and cohort development through co-curricular activities. Scholarship recipients will have access to STEM career development opportunities including individual mentoring by faculty, internships, participation in faculty research, and pathways for job placement. It is anticipated that many of the scholarship recipients will be first-generation college students and the project includes an effort to include the families of scholarship recipients in a way that enables the student's family to appreciate the challenges and opportunities of higher education and to assist in providing the support students may need to complete  STEM degrees.  Scholarships and support for low-income and academically talented students, who may not otherwise be able to obtain STEM degrees, will help to produce a well-trained workforce that will contribute to the nation's economic growth and industrial competitiveness.

While current research provides evidence for the importance of family support, few published studies investigate college completion outcomes when the parents and family members of college students from low-income backgrounds are purposefully informed and included in campus-centered social support activities. This Pacific University S-STEM project will include an effort to specifically inform students' parents or other critical family members about college, including processes such as advising and registration, college milestones such as declaring a major, and opportunities such as internships and research.  Topics will include the essential time commitment required for students to be successful in college, and that time spent away from college studies should be limited to ensure academic success and access to the economic opportunities of STEM careers. Materials will be multi-lingual and designed with sensitivity to relevant cultural values and cultural norms of communication.  The project will study ways to help students' families to understand the investment value for a college education, and thus be more willing and better able to provide emotional support and encouragement for completing college. The results will help to inform the nation's STEM education community about the role of family members in improving retention and degree completion among low-income and academically talented students.

por.por_cntn:
Pacific Scholarships in Mathematics and Science (PSiMS,) funded by the S-STEM program at NSF, aimed to assemble a multidisciplinary cohort of economically disadvantaged students from all four years of their college education, and to support their academic success and transition into STEM post-graduate education and careers. As a small liberal arts and sciences undergraduate college, Pacific University fosters a cohesive and supportive community of STEM students. We have found that meeting regularly with the PSiMS scholars in a seminar setting provides opportunities for both community building and delivery of STEM related education and career information. The PSiMS scholars, freshmen through seniors from all STEM disciplines at Pacific, formed a welcoming and supportive community where more senior students would welcome newer students and help them adjust to college both academically and socially. This seminar course provides PSiMS recipients the following:

  • Introductions to campus academic support through peer tutoring and coaching.
  • Opportunities for social support from peers and faculty.
  • Information about summer research opportunities both on and off campus.
  • Opportunities for PSiMS scholars who participated in summer research to present the results of their work.
  • Guidance in preparing graduate school and employment applications, including writing cover letters, statements of purpose, and resumes.
  • Opportunities to learn about career and educational opportunities in STEM through meetings with Pacific STEM alumni in graduate programs and STEM careers, including one session with STEM high school educators.
  • Graduate program information sessions with representatives from regional STEM graduate programs.
  • Meeting with the program director for Pacific University?s NSF funded Noyce Scholars program.
  • Guidance to families of scholarship recipients in supporting a college student, including a PSiMS newsletter for parents and families. 

 The PSiMS program supported a total of 53 individuals over a five-year period, providing $551,900 to fund a total of in 95 renewable 1-year scholarships. Of the PSiMS scholars, 34 graduated with a STEM major, seven are continuing their STEM studies at Pacific, and the remainder left the program either by transferring from Pacific, changing to a non-stem major, or for financial or academic ineligibility. PSiMS scholars have majored in biology, bioinformatics, chemistry, computer science, environmental science, mathematics, or physics. The gender distribution of scholars was 44% male and 56% female and included individuals identifying as American Indian, Asian, Black, Native Hawaiian, Filipino American, White, and Hispanic. First generation students represented 30% of the PSiMS scholars.

 As part of our evaluation, we surveyed students while in the program and after graduating using retrospective questions that were constructed to have participants report how participating in PSiMS activities influenced their confidence in their educational progress, their sense of belonging and acceptance in a STEM field, and their sense of family support.  Of the respondents to these surveys approximately 33% indicated their understanding and confidence in succeeding in college increased with participation. Furthermore, 71% reported an increase in their knowledge and confidence in their STEM education. 45% of respondents reported an increase in their sense of belonging and acceptance in STEM.  19% of respondents increase in family understanding and support for their STEM education and career.

 We have been able to compile post-graduate outcomes for approximately 82% of graduates from the PSiMS program.  Of the respondents 33% are attending or have graduated from a graduate STEM program and an additional 30% plan to attend after taking one or more ?gap years.? For STEM teaching, 3% have completed a STEM graduate teaching program and are currently teaching, and another 6% are planning to enroll in a graduate STEM teaching program. 42% of respondents are currently in STEM related jobs. 10% of graduates have or are planning on graduate education in a health care field. All survey respondents rated the PSiMS seminar programming in STEM academic success, STEM careers and career preparation as ?helpful? or ?very helpful?. Alumni who completed the survey included free response statements of gratitude for the financial support and the additional academic and personal support from the PSiMS program.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2022
Modified by: Kevin E Johnson
